page.title: 07 RED HOUSE REST HOME
page.content: The Red House was originally connected with the farm next door when it was built in 1785. The bricks came from the old Dumbleton brick works and a lot of the old beams came from the remains of Evesham Abbey. During World War 2 the house was a temporary home for the soldiers who were going to be dropped behind enemy lines. The present owner, Mr Fearnett has made a lot of changes, modernising it with new showers, toilets, baths and bedrooms. There are at present 18 residents and 11 people are employed there. There are 15 rooms and it was made into a residential rest home in 1980. Before it was converted into a rest home it was a private dwelling. The plot on which the Red House stands cover approx. 0.3 of an acre.
